title: US Military will stop using 8-inch floppy disks for its missile system
text:
The US missile control system was developed back in the 60s and 70s (Getty; Reuters)

The US military has decided to retire the use of 8-inch floppy disks for its nuclear missile control system.

The archaic storage solution was cutting-edge at the time the USA’s Strategic Automated Command and Control System (SACCS) was developed – back in the 1960s/1970s.

The system controls launch silos around the country from where the most powerful military in the world can deploy nuclear missiles.

A report from defence site C4isrnet explains the weapons of mass destruction are now controlled by a ‘highly-secure solid state digital storage solution’. Apparently, the switch happened back in June, according to Lt. Col. Jason Rossi, commander of the Air Force’s 595th Strategic Communications Squadron.

Up until June, if the US president ordered a nuclear strike, military officials would have to rely on floppy disks to activate the 70s-era IBM Series /1 mainframe computer that the system runs on.

These little beauties could store up to 80kb of data – gradually that went up to 1.44MB (iStockphoto)

While that may seem ridiculous, officials point out that the age of the system gives it a certain measure of security.

‘I joke with people and say it’s the Air Force’s oldest IT system. But it’s the age that provides that security,’ Rossi said.

‘You can’t hack something that doesn’t have an IP address. It’s a very unique system — it is old and it is very good.’

A conventionally configured ground-launched cruise missile is launched by the U.S. Department of Defense (DOD) during a test (Reuters)

The US Air Force is currently looking at a replacement for SACCS, not least because it takes a long time to train newer engineers on how to use the older tech.
